Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Diversity and Biology of Microbes in Late Paleozoic Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration: Microorganisms, including bacteria, cyanobacteria, microalgae, and various fungi and fungal-like organisms (e.g., Peronsporomycetes), are critical components of all communities today. These organisms certainly performed similar functions in the past, and were responsible for the evolution and sustainability of ancient ecosystems in activities ranging from decomposition to nutrient cycling. Unfortunately, however, relatively little is known about how precisely the individual groups of microorganisms functioned in the geologic past. In this research program, various microorganisms that are three-dimensionally preserved in Early Devonian to Late Carboniferous cherts will be investigated. The Devonian and Carboniferous are important periods of geologic time in which all major lineages of vascular land plants (except angiosperms) and the fundamental architectural principles of their body plan (e.g., roots, shoot axis, leaves) evolved. As a result of this increased plant diversity, the number of ecologically distinct (micro-) habitats increased drastically, which, in turn, has resulted in the evolution of new and specific plant-microbe interactions (e.g., leaf endophytism). Because both microbes and their hosts are preserved in chert, these associations provide an extraordinary opportunity to document the diversity of microbes through an important segment of geologic time, and also to study a number of complex interactions that were critical in the functioning of the ancient terrestrial ecosystems. Some of these interactions include parasitism, saprophytism, and various degrees of mutualistic association. To accomplish the goals of this research agenda an international team was assembled that has expertise with both fossil and extant microbes. The project will encompass four interrelated themes: 1) documenting overall microbe diversity, 2) examining diversity through segments of geologic time in which there are well known host plants, 3) characterizing certain types of mutualistic (mycorrhizal) fungi based on spore wall features used with extant glomeromycoytan fungi, 4) documenting microbe interactions based on host responses. The utilization of structurally preserved organisms is the only method available to directly investigate complex interactions that existed between various microbes and their fossil hosts. Documenting these microorganisms, their associations, and interactions with other organisms will make it possible to trace co-evolutionary trends that can be used together with modern approaches to investigate the evolutionary history of certain types of biological and ecological processes that sustain and drive terrestrial ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted in this project by an international team of geo- and bioscientists investigated the diversity and interactions of fossil microorganisms in three paleoecosystems that are three-dimensionally preserved in a chert matrix and extend from the Lower Devonian (c. 410 Ma) to the Upper Pennsylvanian (c. 299 Ma). Because the fossils from these sites are preserved in chert, they provide an extraordinary opportunity to not only document microbial biodiversity, but also to examine associations and interactions between different organisms that were important as drivers and sustainers of these ecosystems.

Our research indicates that bacteria, cyanobacteria (blue-green algae), fungi, fungal-like organisms, and microalgae were abundant and diverse in all three paleoecosystems, and that many of these organisms entered into complex and highly interrelated interactions with other ecosystem constituents, especially land plants. One interesting facet of research focused on interfungal relationships (i.e. interactions of fungi with other fungi). Previous studies have almost exclusively described local interactions from single specimens, which rarely provided details about the spatial extent of the interactions and the context in which these interrelationships occurred. Within the context of this project, we discovered several interfungal relationships that were analyzed based on larger sample sets of well-preserved specimens.

Fungi were especially abundant and diverse, and thus no doubt played an important role in the functioning of our fossil ecosystems. Articulated specimens from all three sites attest to the existence of several different fungal associations and interactions with land plants. Moreover, numerous fragmented remains of fungi (e.g. hyphae, spores, detached sporangia) occur in abundance. However, attempts to assess fungal diversity and biology based on these fossils are hampered by the fact that the specimens occur detached from the systems on or in which they were produced. Among the most frequently encountered fungal fossils are small, detached fungal reproductive units that differ from one another in size, wall thickness, and sometimes mode of attachment to subtending hyphae. Only a few of them exhibit distinctive structural features that allow for their precise systematic placement. Within the context of this project, we have focused on several forms of fungal reproductive units that were characterized by ancillary coverings in the form of hyphal investments or mantles, which are especially significant because they represent the oldest evidence of hyphal investments in fungi. One of these fungal reproductive units is also significant because it represents one of only two microorganisms from our study sites for which life history stages and ontogenetic development have been reconstructed. The latter study particularly underlined the importance of large sample sets in tracing the features that characterize different developmental stages, and demonstrated that preservation quality matters, and that specimens situated in protected (micro-)environments (e.g., within intact plant tissue or in small voids within litter layers) may yield more or qualitatively superior information than specimens located outside these special environments. This knowledge can be used in future to refine search images and activities for the best-preserved specimens of structurally preserved fossil microorganisms in a chert matrix, and thus can contribute to a more complete documentation and better understanding of ancient microbial life.

The broader impacts components of the project involved education and outreach initiatives that included women and under-represented groups. The study of fossil microbes represents an important educational component that students rarely have access to. In this context we experienced that by illuminating the diversity of fossil microbes, students will have a broader appreciation of the ecology of modern organisms and how they impact the communities in which they live. This project expanded our successful education and human development portfolio using four strategies: 1) public outreach, teaching and mentoring of women and under-represented students in paleobiology; 2) mentoring graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in science and in career trajectories; 3) developing inquiry-based workshops on fossil microbes with the Division of Education, KU Natural History Museum and the Bavarian State Collection, GeoBio Center, and Palaeontological Museum in Munich, Germany; 4) support for workshops for middle school girls in science via the Expanding Your Horizons Program and Si Se Puede Hacer Ciencias y Matematicás, Emporia State University, and the KU Discover Technology Summer Program.
